@debrabrown_ I'm holding on to the last few hours very hard and trying to ignore the thought of tomorrow's alarm!
...and feel grateful that whatever happens next, we had this lovely, lovely summer and nothing can change that ‚òÄÔ∏è‚ù§Ô∏è‚òÄÔ∏è

I'm going to sit with that thought for a bit while I watch another beautiful sunset and bottle up as much of this feeling as I can so that when life inevitably gets noisier and messier again, I can revisit this perfectly long, perfectly enough summer...
That's quite something, really, that after everything that's happened and everything that's changed in the last seven years, it's possible to find your way back to a place that feels this good.
And I think that's the first time I've been able say that without any 'despite' or 'except for' in seven years.

It really has been lovely from start to finish: our holiday, the jobs we ticked off at home, time with friends and family, playing games, reading in the sunshine, walks and time that has actually felt like a pause.

The night before going back to work and I'm thinking it really has been a lovely summer, and it feels both a relief and a surprise to be thinking this without any 'despite' or 'except for' wedging its way in between the good stuff.

@JuliadeCadenet @helen_barnowl @IsabelOakeshott @sajidjavid @NHSEngland I'm Mum of a child receiving treatment for cancer. I know a huge number of oncology families. The pandemic did not delay cancer treatment for children. It made other things difficult, but it didn't delay treatment. Children diagnosed with cancer are treated straight away.

@ChrisSm58292236 @kerrywil75 @sajidjavid @NHSEngland No. It's not a thing. I know a huge number of oncology families and don't know a single one whose child was put on waiting list. There may be waiting lists for adult treatment but the second your child receives a cancer diagnosis, treatment starts. They don't hang around.

@ChrisSm58292236 @kerrywil75 @sajidjavid @NHSEngland No, these are children who are gravely ill who the UK has agreed to take in so that they can continue their vital treatment so they don't needlessly die. Many other countries have made similar agreements.

@RachaelDunlop Yes work like that quite often, but it also depends on how many shared letters between the four words and what order you solve them.

@RachaelDunlop If you have a word with multiple possibilities, you need to eliminate not guess your way through them because you'll not then have enough guesses to correctly guess the other three words.

@RachaelDunlop What I mean is that each correct guess takes a guess so with four words to guess you must make sure that whatever elimination strategies you use, you leave yourself 4 guesses to guess each word correctly otherwise you lose.

@RachaelDunlop I'm finally getting the hang of it. You can't waste guesses on words that have multiple possibilities because you must have 4 guesses to end the game with so only 5 guesses to eliminate letters. I'm losing less often now and I was very proud of a 3,4,5,6 combo the other day!

@ckingwriter Thank you. My 'bit shit' was restrained. I've been swearing a lot today. I'll get my balance back tomorrow. It's exhausting being this angry at the situation!
@PeteDomican It's been feeling so out of control the last few weeks and nothing the government says matches up with what we're seeing in schools. My positive test was inevitable in some respects.
@RegretteRuane I don't feel thoughtful and generous today üòÇüòÇ Thank you ‚ù§

But, blimey, it's really hard to focus on any other positives right now because after the year Peter has had, this is not how it should be ending. Normal positivity will resume tomorrow. Today I just need to stop and say out loud that Everything Is A Bit Shit.

My husband and Peter (both negative) should be allowed to leave self-isolation to attend the appointments and The Christie have protocols in place for these situations to keep everyone safe. So, that's good.
There are positives. There's always positives. The biggest one right now is the reassurance that Peter's radiotherapy should still go ahead on Thursday...
I've been banished to the attic bedroom for the foreseeable to try and minimise the possibility of passing it on. There's nothing else we can do now except wait and hope.
And now it's all been taken out of my hands by Covid. He will miss all but the last two days of school, providing that no one else in the family tests positive in the meantime.

...with all the health professionals involved in his care to make sure that appointments and treatment wherever possible didn't stop him from joining in with his outdoor adventure days or the bikeability course or his last few weeks of school.

Peter leaves primary school forever a week on Wednesday. It has been a juggling act all year trying to keep him in school as much as possible around his treatment but no more so than in this last term when I have unashamedly made a pain in the arse of myself...

And... I've just tested positive for Covid. 
I'm not particularly unwell - a bit of a head cold and that's it so it's easy to say it could be a lot worse except... the timing is so incredibly shit.

Supply teachers have been hard to find. My school has struggled to stay open.I have tried to be careful. I have followed all the rules. I have washed my hands & worn my mask & tried to keep my distance. I have kept faith in my status as a double-vaccinated person (AZ) since April

After things seeming to settle down, the last few weeks in school have been turning back into a nightmare. While the government talks about lifting restrictions in just a week's time, we have seen multiple children & adults testing positive and many classes self-isolating...
...to find more classes have isolated and more teachers have tested positive. But I kept going because, mostly, it felt like the right thing to do.

Most of the time, it felt like the right decision because I love my job and it was a good and healthy distraction from all the stresses of Peter's treatment. It's not been without stress because at times when numbers have been increasing it's been scary coming in each week...

For the whole of this academic year, I have been putting myself and my family (and Peter most of all) at risk by going in and teaching at a large school in an area that has had consistently high numbers for a fair proportion of that year.

Positivity doesn't solve everything. Sometimes, when the world is slinging crap at you day after day it's not possible to keep marching forward with a big smile on your face. Sometimes you just have to stop & say out loud that Everything Is A Bit Shit (thread).
